items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 01:00am and 03:00am tomorrow morning, Friday 28th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea seafront may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.76 mAODN at 02:00am, on Friday 28th October, which is 0.22m above tide tables, wind Force 4, southerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am on Friday 28th October.

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: This flood warning has now been removed as the morning high tide has passed. However we will closely monitor the situation and reissue if necessary.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: The Flood Alert has now been removed. However, a further Flood Alert may be issued tomorrow morning for the around midday high tide on 28/10/2022.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message: The Flood Alert has now been removed. However, a further Flood Alert may be issued tomorrow morning for the around midday high tide on 27/10/2022.Â

This Flood Alert for the Mersey Estuary at Warrington has now been removed. The forecast indicates no current flood risk from high tides and no further impacts are expected. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if necessary.

This flood alert remains in force as a result of high spring tides. We are not expecting today's 27/10/2022 lunchtime tide to reach flood alert level however today's 27/10/2022 midnight tide is forecast to reach flood alert level. Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 17:00 PM on 27/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall has been issued as strong winds and unsettled weather may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast this evening, Thursday 27/10/2022. The particular area at risk is around Kilnsea village. Flooding of low lying land and coastal roads is possible between 20:00 and 21:30 on Thursday 27/10/2022. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 5pm 27/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert for the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea remains in force as strong winds and unsettled weather may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast this evening Thursday 27/10/2022. Areas most at risk include low lying coastal frontages, in particular around Kilnsea Caravan Park, Southfield Farm coastal side and Spurn Road. Flooding of low lying land and coastal roads is possible from 7:30 to 9:15pm. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 5 pm Thursday 27/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.65mAOD at 16:45 on 27/10/22 and 4.70mAOD at 05:00 on 28/10/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are at their peak. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 22 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next 2 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 28/10/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: This flood alert has now been removed. We will continue to monitor the local water levels and weather closely and reissue the alert if necessary.

Tides are expected to be high during coming tides. Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. The first forecast high water is at 10:30 AM on Thursday 27/10/2022 with a level of 1.25mAODN with southerly force 4 winds. The second forecast high water is at 10:30 PM on Thursday 27/10/2022 with a level of 1.21mAODN and southerly force 4 winds. A third forecast high water is at 10:30 AM on 28/10/2022 with a level of 1.28mAODN and south-westerly force 6 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more detail refer to local tide tables.) Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of these times. We are monitoring the situation and will close locks and flood gates if needed. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. Consider activating any property flood protection products in Christchurch Harbour. This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 28/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

A tidal surge is expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 9am and 11am on Friday 28/10/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.3m to 7.8m at 9.45am and Newport 7.0m to 7.4m at 9.30am on 28/10/22.   
Coastal conditions should ease for the high tide on Friday morning, 28/10/22 by midday. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated  by midday on 28/10/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Friday morning. High water at Exmouth is at 9.15am, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 5 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 1.3m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 360mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the forecast high tide level at Exmouth is 2.49 mAOD, this is 0.36 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced, however, gale force winds are still forecast, so take care near coastal paths and promenades.

As a result of spring tides and strong winds, wave overtopping and spray is expected for Berwick Between Bridges between 15:00 and 17:30 (BST) this afternoon, 27/10/2022. 

We are not expecting any property flooding or to issue Flood Warnings. Areas most at risk are by the estuary, including riverside footpaths and low-lying land on the south bank of the Tweed estuary. Take care and avoid these areas.  
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 27/10/2022, or as the situation changes.
The Flood Alert has now been removed. However, a further Flood Alert may be issued tomorrow morning for the around midday high tide on 27/10/2022.Â

items.description: Irish Sea from Hilbre Island to Heswall
items.message: This Flood Alert for the Irish Sea from Hilbre Island to Heswall has now been removed. The forecast indicates there is no longer risk to areas as water overtopping and spray has reduced and no further impacts are expected. We will continue to monitor the situation.

The unsettled weather which brought strong winds and elevated tide levels along the south coast has now cleared the area.

The early afternoon tide at Beaulieu (12:04 and 14:24 on 26/10/2022) came in 24cm under forecast.

Over the next few days, the tide level is gradually lowering, and no further impacts are currently expected.

The unsettled weather which brought strong winds and elevated tide levels along the south coast has now cleared the area.

The early afternoon tide at Portsmouth (12:30 on 26/10/2022) came in 15cm under forecast.

Over the next few days, the tide level is gradually lowering, and no further impacts are currently expected.

The unsettled weather which brought strong winds and elevated tide levels along the south coast has now cleared the area.

The midday tide at Cowes (12:00 on 26/10/2022) came in 10cm under forecast.

Over the next few days, the tide level is gradually lowering, and no further impacts are currently expected.

The unsettled weather which brought strong winds and elevated tide levels along the south coast has now cleared the area.

The early afternoon tide at Southampton (12:04 and 14:24 on 26/10/2022) came in 14cm under forecast.

Over the next few days, the tide level is gradually lowering, and no further impacts are currently expected.

The unsettled weather which brought strong winds and elevated tide levels along the south coast has now cleared the area.

The early afternoon tide at Southampton (12:04 and 14:24 on 26/10/2022) came in 14cm under forecast.

Over the next few days, the tide level is gradually lowering, and no further impacts are currently expected.
